32.57.text:
BILL RUDIN: Happy New Year
to everyone. Hope everyone

34.80.text:
had a wonderful Martin
Luther King holiday and

38.17.text:
thanks for joining us.
Before I start the program,

42.14.text:
I'd just like to
take a moment to remember

46.68.text:
our great governor Mario
Cuomo. His leadership and

51.25.text:
devotion to New York was
tremendous and we all feel

55.09.text:
his loss. Our condolences
Governor to you and the

60.06.text:
entire Cuomo family. I'm
sure right now Mario and

64.60.text:
Lou are up at the
Association for a Better

67.80.text:
heaven breakfast looking
down on us gathered here

72.64.text:
with such pride, their
spirits are definitely in

76.84.text:
the room with us this
morning. There are many

82.52.text:
distinguished individuals
who are here with us

85.12.text:
this morning. Heads of
businesses, labor, civic

96.86.text:
non-for-profits and I
would be here for an hour

100.33.text:
if I started introducing
everyone but there's just

103.04.text:
a few that I just want to
recognize. The dean of our

117.78.text:
Charlie started his
career as a congressman

122.96.text:
that ABNY was started. He
has led a long and

127.69.text:
distinguished career and
has fought so hard for our

130.83.text:
city and our state. And
Charlie as you embark on

134.40.text:
your last term in Congress
we know you will continue

137.90.text:
to fight and be a strong
advocate for our city and state.

141.81.text:
Thank you for your
friendship for your service

146.21.text:
and we're so happy
that you're here with us today.

148.52.text:
And Charlie, are
you a follower or a leader?

152.32.text:
Charlie knows what
that means. Congressman

155.59.text:
Carolyn Maloney is here
with us also, thank you Carolyn.

165.90.text:
She fought the
good fight for us in

168.04.text:
representing an important
issue that was just passed

171.41.text:
and signed just a couple
weeks ago in Congress and

174.61.text:
that is the extension of
TRIA. And it's apropos

179.51.text:
that we are going to be
discussing infrastructure

183.18.text:
today and with that TRIA
passed that would have

185.79.text:
been thousands of jobs
lost in our economy

187.99.text:
would've definitely taken
it. Thank you Carolyn for

199.97.text:
in a bipartisan way things
can get done in Washington

202.77.text:
believe it or not. We also
are honored to have with

206.34.text:
us our old friend Carl
McCall. Carl where are you?

209.91.text:
Thank you for being
here. SUNY chancellor.

214.31.text:
I also want to recognize two
gentlemen and their paths

219.15.text:
are crossing Larry
Schwartz secretary of the

222.32.text:
Governor thank you for
your tremendous efforts

225.63.text:
and work on behalf of our
state and we wish you the

227.99.text: best of luck Larry. Thank you.

233.80.text: And the man who will be

234.33.text:
taking his spot Bill
Mulrow, an old friend of

237.67.text:
ours and incredible public
servant and we wish you

241.04.text:
the best of luck Bill and look
forward to working with you.

247.71.text:
I know there are
other members of the

249.15.text:
administration who are
here with us this morning.

251.15.text:
And Governor we
congratulate you on your

253.45.text:
tremendous efforts to
bring in new blood into

257.66.text:
the administration and we
wish you and your team the

259.76.text:
best of luck. Thank you
for being here this morning.

264.26.text:
During the long
history of our city and

266.33.text:
state there's been one
common thread running

269.70.text:
throughout. And that is
the strength of our

272.41.text:
leaders in particular when
leadership is needed the most.

277.48.text:
When New York is in
crisis, whether the result

280.58.text:
of Mother Nature, external
threats, or self-inflicted

285.85.text:
and our lights go out,
we've been always blessed

288.79.text:
with great leaders who
have stepped forward with

292.46.text:
flashlights in hand to
light the path for all of us.

297.20.text:
We're very fortunate
for the leadership of

299.87.text:
Governor Andrew Cuomo who
has shined a light on the

302.87.text:
critical issues that have
challenged our state

313.01.text:
development and job growth,
resiliency and so much more.

321.92.text:
Cuomo has been one of the
private sector's greatest

324.96.text:
partners in making New
York a more business

328.09.text:
friendly state. He
understands the important

330.86.text:
roles that state
government plays in the

333.60.text:
strengthening of our
economy and creating an

340.64.text:
Governor Cuomo started
bringing fiscal responsibility

343.71.text:
back to Albany passing
four consecutive on time

347.45.text:
budgets for the
first time in forty years.

358.69.text:
in line he's been able to
cut taxes. Thanks to the

362.56.text:
governor, New York now has
the lowest middle income

365.87.text:
tax rate since 1953, the
lowest corporate income

369.77.text:
tax rate since 1968 and
the lowest manufacturing

373.67.text:
tax rate since 1917. You
can applaud on that one too.

383.18.text:
All three rating
agencies have taken notice

385.29.text:
of the progress that we
have made in our state.

387.85.text:
Finch, Moody's and S & P
have now given the state

392.03.text:
its highest credit rating
in over forty years.

401.23.text:
The governor recognizes that
infrastructure is the core

404.40.text:
of any economic engine. He
has made great commitments

413.41.text:
He's launched a twenty five
billion dollar state wide

416.12.text:
recovery strategy aimed at
transforming New York's

422.26.text:
and coastal protection
systems. He's also created

426.53.text:
New York works task force
composed of leading

429.80.text:
professionals charged with
coordinating and spending

433.63.text:
one hundred seventy four
billion dollars in

440.44.text:
decades of delay Governor
Cuomo is finally

443.98.text:
rebuilding the new New
York bridge, replacing the

447.71.text:
Tappan Zee saving the
state a billion dollars

451.75.text:
through innovative design
build process. Governor

457.32.text:
your vision and leadership
have been invaluable to

460.39.text:
our city and state and we
are grateful for your

463.50.text:
ongoing commitment to
attracting and retaining

466.50.text:
jobs, keeping our fiscal
house in order, protecting

470.47.text:
expanding economic drivers
of New York and making the

473.77.text:
critical infrastructure
investments we need to

476.91.text:
ensure that our empire
state remains globally

479.81.text:
competitive. Governor as
you light the path forward

484.25.text:
we stand behind you with
our flashlights ready to

487.35.text:
help in any way we can.
Ladies and gentlemen

490.86.text:
please join me in
welcoming Governor Andrew Cuomo.

511.28.text:
GOVERNOR ANDREW CUOMO: Thank
you. Thank you.

517.45.text:
Thank you very much.
First to Bill Rudin and

524.39.text:
ABNY, what a really
phenomenal job this

528.09.text:
organization does. Let's
give Bill a round of applause.

536.20.text:
And I think he's
right. I think his father

538.24.text:
and my father are in the
same place and I think

542.34.text:
they're probably together
right now looking down and

546.85.text:
listening to Bill's speech
and listening to my speech

550.45.text:
and they'll be doing their
running commentary and

554.29.text:
frankly I'm glad I'm not
hearing it. They had a

559.93.text:
very long relationship,
they were very fond of

563.30.text:
each other, they were
together when New York was

565.67.text:
going through really tough
times. And if you want to

569.44.text:
talk about two people who
defined leadership and

573.41.text:
defined partnership and
defined coming together

577.58.text:
and finding commonalities
to get through tough

580.45.text:
times, it was Lou Rudin
and Mario Cuomo and their

586.85.text:
lesson of leadership. We
have a lot to learn from

591.16.text:
especially during these
difficult days. So it's my

593.99.text:
pleasure to be with all of
you today. I have my team

598.30.text:
members here. You heard about 
Larry Schwartz and

601.60.text:
Bill Mulrow. We're also joined
by Tom Prendergast who

604.67.text:
runs the M.T.A.. Give him
a round of applause.

614.51.text:
We have Pat Foye who runs the
Port Authority who is here

619.82.text:
and we have Joan McDonald
who's the Department

631.26.text: There are a roomful of people

633.53.text:
who could be acknowledged
but I was sitting next to one

636.44.text:
gentleman who taught me so much
about leadership and he's

640.01.text:
here Mayor David Dinkins. Let's
give him a round of applause.

648.85.text:
Now this is a new year. Happy
New Year to everyone.

650.92.text:
This is the beginning of the
year and it's traditional at

652.92.text:
the beginning of the year the
government the leaders the

655.59.text:
executives lay out a
vision for that government

659.79.text:
for the year. President
does the State of the

663.23.text:
Union Address, governors
do the state of the state

666.03.text:
address which is a large
overview of what their

671.00.text:
plans are for the year.
This is going to be my

673.21.text:
fifth state of the state.
And hopefully you learn a

677.21.text:
little something every
time as you go along. And

680.85.text:
this is probably the most
robust state of the state

684.02.text:
that I've done. We have
close to one hundred

687.52.text:
significant proposals to
try to get done with the

690.79.text:
legislature. And as you
heard we've had a new

693.99.text:
level of functionality
with the legislature we

696.70.text:
passed four budgets in a
row. This was a

699.20.text:
legislature which
historically was very slow

702.67.text:
to get anything done.
We've been moving quite

705.71.text:
well. We want to now test
that new capacity by

709.38.text:
actually putting on a more
ambitious agenda so we do

713.71.text:
the state of the state
address tomorrow but there

715.72.text:
were so many items that
really deserved detailed

720.49.text:
discussion that it didn't
fit in the state of the

722.96.text:
state so we're taking a
few pieces and I'd like to

726.79.text:
discuss them separately.
And one of them is the

732.57.text:
primarily for downstate
New York because the truth

735.60.text:
is it's been overlooked
for too long. When

739.81.text:
government runs into a
period of dysfunction or

742.91.text:
when government runs into
a period of stretched

746.08.text:
resources the first thing
to go is the construction

750.75.text:
budget or the
reconstruction budget or

752.85.text:
the maintenance budget.
And in many ways that's

755.96.text:
the last thing that should
be sacrificed because

759.69.text:
that's what keeps you
competitive. And this year

762.20.text:
I want to catch up for a
lot of the work that we

766.40.text:
haven't done over the past
few years and I want to

769.74.text:
move forward so we have a
slideshow presentation for

774.11.text:
you today that will run
through our plans

778.71.text:
relatively quickly I hope.
What makes New York,

782.62.text:
New York? It's our spirit.
It's our audacity, our

786.09.text:
ambition, our
aggressiveness, which is a

788.66.text:
positive the way we do it.
We attract and we move

793.36.text:
people and we do it
quickly and we do it

795.66.text:
safely and we do it
inexpensively.

799.07.text:
And New York historically is a
built environment.

803.64.text:
This is a built space. And we
build bigger, we build

807.87.text:
faster, we build stronger
than anyone else and we

810.71.text:
always have. There was no
building challenge that we

814.55.text:
shied away from. They
would say, well that's

817.25.text:
never been done before and
we would say, great then

820.15.text:
we should do that. Right?
Brooklyn Bridge, Verrazano

832.27.text:
know what's going to
happen with the economy.

834.37.text:
We say, let's build the
tallest building ever

838.94.text:
right when the economy is
at its lowest point. Five

845.85.text:
tunnels, which many
engineers said were

849.18.text:
impossible to build when
we did it. A sixty mile

853.39.text:
aqueduct system to get
water down from the

856.09.text:
mid Hudson. That's the New
York spirit. That's the

860.33.text:
spirit that built New York
and that's the spirit that

863.80.text:
will keep New York the
number one destination.

867.67.text:
The transportation system
then, is the circulatory

871.37.text:
system that makes it all
work and that's what we

875.07.text:
want to rebuild over these
next few years starting

879.98.text:
with our airports because
that is the gateway to

883.05.text:
business. And we really
have not kept pace with

887.29.text:
the rest of the world and
our competitors. You look

890.29.text:
at any report it will talk
about how the New York

893.89.text:
airports sorely lag in
terms of development.

899.77.text:
The vice president said, if I
blindfolded you and took

902.30.text:
you to LaGuardia airport
in New York you must think

905.04.text:
I must be in some third
world country.

907.97.text:
Not the most warm and fuzzy
comment ever made.

912.48.text:
But instructive nonetheless.
New York is a world class

918.38.text:
location but our airports
are outdated and lagged

921.75.text:
behind our competitors
there are some phenomenal

925.19.text:
developments in airports
around the world.

930.56.text:
And not only the usual suspects
but South Korea,

934.00.text:
Hong Kong, the Dubai airport is
truly a phenomenon.

940.27.text:
So this fall we launched a
design competition to

944.74.text:
modernize our region's
airports starting with

948.21.text:
J.F.K. and LaGuardia and
we asked the designers to

952.72.text:
be creative. The sky's the
limit start with a blank

956.09.text:
piece of paper and just
give us a vision for the

960.43.text:
most competitive airport
on the planet.

964.30.text:
That was the charge. And we got
some really exciting

969.54.text:
designs back, eleven
between J.F.K. and

972.67.text:
LaGuardia. For LaGuardia,
the main problems are

975.98.text:
limited public
transportation. It's a bad

978.81.text:
use of space and very few
what we would now call

982.48.text:
modern amenities. The
proposals that came back

987.12.text:
were really breathtaking.
An entirely redesigned

990.82.text:
terminal. Use of the
Marine Air terminal in a

996.06.text:
much more efficient and
incorporated manner with

999.77.text:
the airport operations. A
hotel and business center

1004.74.text:
located at LaGuardia so
people who just want to

1008.01.text:
come to the airport,
transact business,

1011.41.text:
they could do exactly that.
Personal rapid transit

1014.98.text:
movers or people could be
moved across the airport

1019.15.text:
in a relatively short
period of time. And State

1022.39.text:
of the art dining and
amenities, I'm partial to

1025.56.text:
Pete Luger, that's why we
put that in the sign but

1028.76.text:
that's only illustrative
in as governor you get a

1032.13.text:
few prerogatives and
that's the extent of mine.

1037.50.text:
Regional ferry access to
get you to the airport and

1042.01.text:
something that we're going
to do, which I'm very

1044.18.text:
excited about, which is a
new train service that

1048.58.text:
will get to LaGuardia. You
can't get to LaGuardia by

1051.95.text:
train today. And that
really is inexcusable and

1057.26.text:
that we're going to change
over the next several

1062.23.text:
years. We will have and we
will construct an air

1066.73.text:
train that will connect
with the route seven

1070.87.text:
subway line and the Long
Island Railroad at

1074.71.text:
Willett's Point and will
take you into LaGuardia.

1078.78.text:
That is about a mile and a
half construction.

1082.35.text:
It will run along the Grand
Central Parkway in an area

1087.12.text:
that we believe won't
create an undue burden to

1090.76.text:
any of the neighboring
structures and connect a

1094.86.text:
one ride from the subway
system or the Long Island

1099.90.text:
Railroad to LaGuardia,
which is truly long

1104.17.text:
overdue. The final design
submissions for LaGuardia,

1108.54.text:
we're looking for a high
speed ferry terminal that

1111.98.text:
goes from LaGuardia to
Manhattan. The redesign of

1115.21.text:
the Marine Air terminal
and including it into

1117.82.text:
LaGuardia Airport, a hotel
business center,

1121.52.text:
retail shopping, personal rapid
transit and the rail

1124.99.text:
access that we're going to
be building in any event.

1128.69.text:
J.F.K. is in a similar
situation, probably worse.

1135.94.text:
access between terminals,
limited expansion ability.

1140.57.text:
Again we've gotten all
sorts of exciting

1143.71.text:
proposals that have come
in. Some have reinvisioned

1147.31.text:
the entire airport with
ferry lines, train services,

1151.15.text:
faster connections, etc.
All include better access

1158.46.text:
because that is going to
be the key. A centralized

1162.70.text:
hub at J.F.K. A new hub
interior. And our

1170.40.text:
requirements for the final
design will be a world

1176.68.text:
accessible parking and
improved mass transit.

1181.08.text:
Long term we're looking at
possibilities for

1184.32.text:
redesigning the airways,
the landing ways, which

1189.12.text:
requires federal approval
but I'm sure with

1195.16.text:
we'll get that in a matter
of weeks, if even weeks.

1198.83.text:
Given their ability to do
their job the way only

1201.77.text:
they can do it. But longer
term actually

1205.00.text:
repositioning the runways
would make a significant

1208.54.text:
difference. Today we're
going to appoint a

1210.84.text:
committee. The committee's
job is to review the

1214.21.text:
proposals that have come
in. And take them to the

1218.78.text:
next level, which will be
the final submission. They

1223.09.text:
will meet with the bidders
who have provided bids

1227.46.text:
thus far, talk about the
requirements and also

1231.16.text:
coordinate these bids with
any outstanding RFP's that

1237.30.text:
the Port Authority or
M.T.A. have outstanding to

1241.01.text:
find out how to do this in
the fastest way possible.

1245.85.text:
Dan Tishman who you all
know who is one of the

1249.48.text:
premier builders on the
planet in my opinion

1252.75.text:
especially in this regard
has agreed to be chairman

1256.56.text:
and I guarantee the people
of this state that he's

1259.56.text:
going to be worth every
penny of the dollar he

1262.33.text:
gets paid to do this job
and we thank him very much

1266.30.text:
for doing it. Query: How
many New York airports

1277.28.text:
serve the New York City
region? Who has the

1281.55.text:
answer? Carolyn Maloney.
New York City region, that

1289.09.text:
was the kicker in the
question. You were going

1291.52.text:
to add Teterboro. Four New
York City airports,

1295.13.text:
Stewart and Republic. We
have never really planned

1298.96.text:
an airport system. We talk
about you know J.F.K. as

1301.87.text:
J.F.K., LaGuardia's as
LaGuardia but we have

1305.04.text:
Stewart Airport and we
have Republic Airport,

1307.44.text:
Republic Airport is on
Long Island, Stewart is in

1310.64.text:
the mid Hudson, and we've
never incorporated them

1314.48.text:
into a system before and
we want to do that now. We

1318.38.text:
want to transform Stewart
into a cargo destination

1323.36.text:
to meet the growing
demands we have for cargo.

1326.29.text:
Stewart is one of the
longest runway in the

1330.00.text:
northeast because it was a
former military base. It

1333.47.text:
has probably one of the
best accesses to major

1338.24.text:
transportation. It's right
off the Thruway, New York

1341.31.text:
State Thruway, and it's
right off 84. We're going

1345.81.text:
to make the land
surrounding Stewart

1348.85.text:
Airport a tax free zone.
So it will basically be a

1354.75.text:
free trade zone in New
York State. There'll be no

1358.76.text:
New York State taxes in
the geographic area around

1363.43.text:
Stewart. So for cargo
companies that want to

1366.33.text:
locate at Stewart Airport,
bring goods in bring goods out,

1370.20.text:
there'll be no New
York State taxation. We

1374.64.text:
also want to take the
current cargo that comes

1378.54.text:
into J.F.K. and move that
cargo shipment up to

1383.02.text:
Stewart, freeing up more
space at J.F.K., getting

1386.95.text:
the traffic out of New
York City and moving it

1391.16.text:
towards upstate New York.
Republic Airport is the

1394.39.text:
same thing, it's on Long
Island. It has easy access

1398.23.text:
to major roads. We're also
going to make the land

1402.84.text:
around Republic Airport a
tax free zone, what we

1406.47.text:
call a start up zone, no
state taxes. So any

1409.51.text:
business that locates
there will pay no state

1412.48.text:
taxes and we believe it'll
be an economic incentive.

1416.08.text:
The Republic airport is
currently owned by the

1418.08.text:
Department of
Transportation. We want to

1420.09.text:
transfer to a private
operator. You can run

1422.86.text:
commuter flights to Long
Island. If you're going to

1425.26.text:
Long Island on business
you don't have to land at

1427.39.text:
J.F.K. or LaGuardia, you
can fly right to Long

1430.73.text:
Island and also make it a
private plane operating

1435.10.text:
terminal so you don't have
to leave the state to

1438.54.text:
access a private plane,
you can do it right at

1442.07.text:
Republic. Second we want
to expand public

1444.94.text:
transportation. 8.5
million people per day are

1449.21.text:
served by the M.T.A.
That's why Tom Prendergast

1452.58.text:
gets the big bucks.
Seventy percent of all

1455.69.text:
subway riders in the
nation ride M.T.A. Forty

1460.93.text:
percent of all rail,
twenty percent of all bus.

1465.30.text:
And the use of the public
transportation is growing

1468.43.text:
and it should grow, we're
looking at a fifteen

1470.60.text:
percent increase by 2030.
To keep pace with that

1472.81.text:
we're going to have to
keep pace with investing

1474.81.text:
and building the M.T.A.
We're building nine

1479.18.text:
hundred new subway cars,
which will be a

1482.61.text:
significant update of the
entire fleet. Eighteen

1486.12.text:
hundred next generation

Somewhere along the way we

and it's focused more on

is higher than any other

Two hundred and
fifty thousand students

2937.03.text:
